Arroyo-Cabrales, J. & Perez, S. 2008. Myotis californicus. In: IUCN 2012. IUCN Red List of Threatened Species. Version 2012.1. <www.iucnredlist.org>. Downloaded on 11 July 2012.

Pp. 63–72 in Proceedings of the Third Biennial Conference of Research on the Colorado Plateau, Transactions and Proceedings Series NPS/NRNAU/NRTP-97/12, USDI National Park Service.

central Nevada. Great Basin Naturalist, 59:213-220.
Faxla, G. 2007. Winter foraging of silver-haired and California myotis bats in western Washington. Northwestern Naturalist, 88(2):98-100.

Harris, J. 1990. California myotis. In Zeiner, D.C., W.F.Laudenslayer, Jr., K.E. Mayer, and M. White, eds. 1988-1990. California's Wildlife. Vol. I-III. California Depart. of Fish and Game, Sacramento, California.
Maser, C., B.R. Mate, J.F. Franklin and C.T. Dyrness. 1981. Natural history of Oregon coast mammals. Pacific Northwest Forest and Range Expt. Sta., USDA, Forest Service, Gen Tech. Rep. PNW-133:1-496.
habitat_description:
Myotis californicus is adapted to a wide range of habitats, from arid grasslands (Fenton and Bell, 1979; Jackson and Herder, 1997; Arizona Department of Fish and Game, 2004; Arroyo-Cabrales and Perez, 2008) and desert shrublands (Krutzsch, 1954; Hirshfeld et al., 1977; Harris, 1990; Fitzgerald et al., 1994; Jackson and Herder, 1997; Kuenzi et al., 1999) to montane forests  (Harris, 1990; Brigham et al., 1997; Jackson and Herder, 1997; Barclay and Brigham, 2001) and humid coastal forests (Maser et al., 1981; Faxla, 2007; Arroyo-Cabrales and Perez, 2008).

They have also be documented in urban parks (Falxa, 2007), chaparral (Harris, 1990), sagebrush (Oliver, 2000), pinyon-juniper woodlands (Fitzgerald et al., 1994; Jackson and Herder, 1997; Kuenzi et al., 1999), oak groves (Krutzsch, 1954), riparian hardwoods (Krutzsch, 1954; Maser et al., 1981; Kuenzi et al., 1999), montane grassland with quaking aspen (Foster et al., 1997), immature conifer forest (Maser et al., 1981), ponderosa pine woodland and forest (Maser et al., 1981), and open water (Woodsworth, 1981; Kuenzi et al., 1999; Geluso, 2007).

The species is known to roost in buildings, bridges, hardwood foliage, bark, rock crevices, caves, mines, snags, and tunnels (Krutzsch, 1954; Hoffman, 1969; Woodsworth, 1981; Christy and West, 1993).

The species avoids alpine and subalpine environments (Jackson and Herder, 1997; Arizona Department of Fish and Game, 2004; Bogan, M.A. and A.L. Chung-MacCoubrey, personal communication) and is suspected to avoid large expanses of barren land (Genoways et al., 1979).

In the southwest, the species has been documented from near sea level (Krutzsch, 1954; Arizona Department of Fish and Game, 2004) to elevations reaching 2744 m (Shuster, 1957; Foster et al., 1997; Jackson and Herder, 1997; Oliver, 2000; Arizona Department of Fish and Game, 2004). Near GAP’s Northwest modeling region, the M. californicus has been documented at elevations up to 2290 m (Fitzgerald et al., 1994).

Though the species often forages over and near open water (Krutzsch, 1954; Kuenzi et al., 1999), such conditions are not required for suitable habitat (Fenton and Bell, 1979).
